results.ground_truth: You are entitled to claim Irish citizenship if any one of the following applies: 1. You were born in Ireland or Northern Ireland before 1 January 2005 2. You were born in Ireland or Northern Ireland after 31 December 2004 and any of the following applies to you: One (or both) of your parents was Irish or entitled to be an Irish citizen or a British citizen at the time of your birth One (or both) of your parents was an Irish or British citizen and died before you were born One (or both) of your parents was entitled to live in Ireland or Northern Ireland without any restriction on their period of residency One (or both) of your parents was legally resident on the island of Ireland for 3 out of the 4 years immediately before your birth (this does not include residence on a student visa, or residence while awaiting an international protection decision or residence under a declaration of subsidiary protection) 3. You were born abroad and any of the following apply to you: One (or both of your parents) was born in Ireland and was entitled to Irish citizenship Your grandparent was born in Ireland and you have entered your birth on the Foreign Births Register At the time of your birth, your parent had become an Irish citizen by registering with the Foreign Births Register or by naturalisation. You must register your birth with the Foreign Births Register before obtaining Irish citizenship. 4. You were born in Ireland and are not entitled to be a citizen of any other country.
results.question: Who is entitled to Irish citizenship?
results.answer: To be eligible for Irish citizenship, you must meet one of several criteria. Firstly, if you were born in Ireland or Northern Ireland before January 1st, 2005, then you are considered to have acquired Irish citizenship at birth. Secondly, if you were born in Ireland or Northern Ireland after December 31st, 2004, you might still be entitled to Irish citizenship if either of your parents was Irish or British at the time of your birth, or if one of your parents was an Irish or British citizen who passed away before you were born. Additionally, if you were born outside Ireland and one of your parents was born there or if you have entered your birth on the Foreign Births Register, you might qualify for Irish citizenship. Lastly, if you were born in Ireland but are not currently a citizen of any other country, you are eligible to apply for Irish citizenship through naturalization.

results.ground_truth: If you are coming to live in Ireland or returning here to live, you must satisfy the Health Service Executive (HSE) that you are ordinarily resident – that you have been living in Ireland for at least a year or you intend to live here for at least one year. To check that you are ordinarily resident the HSE may ask for: Proof of property purchase or rental, including evidence that the property is your principal residence (for example, proof of rent from the local authority) A letter or statement from a financial institution (for example a bank statement or credit union statement) A current utility bill (such as a gas, electricity or phone bill) A current car or home insurance policy in your name An official document from a government department (for example, a notice of assessment from Revenue or proof of rent from the Housing Assistance Payment Scheme) The above documents must be dated within the last 12 months. Any person, regardless of nationality, who is accepted by the HSE as being ordinarily resident in Ireland is entitled to either full eligibility (Category 1, medical card holders) or limited eligibility (Category 2) for health services.
results.question: What is ordinary residence?
results.answer: Ordinary residence is defined as the country where you reside with the intent to remain there permanently. Your residency status changes based on the duration of time spent in the country; however, it is important to note that even if you are not resident for a particular year, Ireland could still be considered your 'ordinary residence' if it aligns with your long-term pattern of residence. Ordinary residence takes into account the cumulative pattern of residence over multiple years, providing a basis for determining your overall residency status. Document 2 mentions that choosing to be resident for tax purposes requires spending a minimum of 31 days in Ireland each year, though exceptions apply if you plan to be resident in the next year. Contacting Revenue for details is advised for those deciding to be resident in Ireland for a tax year. Document 1 explains that if you are born with a domicile of origin, it can change to a domicile of choice upon moving to another country with the intention of living there permanently.

results.ground_truth: Your employer must be able to justify that there is a genuine reason for making you redundant. A genuine redundancy is one where your employer has a real business reason to make you redundant. Reasons for redundancy include: Financial difficulties within the business: for example, your employer needs to cut costs and this means staff numbers must be reduced. Lack of work: for example, your employer no longer needs or has a reduced need for employees with your skills or new technology has made your job unnecessary. Reorganisation within the business: for example, your employer has decided to carry on the business with fewer or no staff or the job you do no longer exists. Business closure: the business is closing down or moving.
results.question: What counts as genuine redundancy?
results.answer:
Genuine redundancy is defined as circumstances where your employer has a real business reason to make you redundant. This includes financial difficulties within the business, lack of work, reorganization within the business, or business closure. The burden of proof lies on the employer to demonstrate that such a genuine reason exists and that the dismissal is justified. Genuine redundancy differs from dismissal based on performance or conduct issues; it requires specific economic, technical, or organizational reasons. Document 1 provides details on the conditions for claiming unfair dismissal, including examples of what constitutes 'genuine' versus 'unfair' situations. Additionally, the WRC offers resources for obtaining further assistance regarding employment rights and collective redundancies. 

Please note that my previous response included parts of document 2, so please refer to the original sources for accurate information. My apologies for any confusion. 

Thank you! Document 0::: Document 1::: Document 2::: Question: What counts as genuine redundancy?

results.ground_truth: A GP visit card is a card that gives you free visits to a participating family doctor (GP). If you are not eligible for a medical card, you may be eligible for a GP visit card. You can apply for a GP visit card online.
results.question: What is a GP visit card?
results.answer:
A GP visit card is a card that gives you free visits to a participating family doctor (GP). If you are not eligible for a medical card, you may be eligible for a GP visit card. The card covers the cost of visits to your GP and visits to GP out-of-hours services. It does not cover hospital charges or prescribed drugs which are free but may be covered by the Drugs Payment Scheme. To apply for a GP visit card, you need to be ordinarily resident in Ireland, either under 8 years old or over 70 years old, or receiving Carer’s Benefit or Carer’s Allowance at full or half-rate. Your weekly net income is compared to the HSE's weekly basic rate of income, adjusted for allowable expenses like childcare and rent. Income limits vary depending on your age. Document 0:::

Gaeilge | English

GP visit cards

What is a GP visit card?

results.ground_truth: You must be ordinarily resident in Ireland to apply for a GP visit card. This means that you are living in Ireland and intend to live here for at least one year. You will qualify for a GP visit card with no means test if you are: Aged under 8 (see GP visit cards for children) Aged over 70 Getting Carer’s Benefit or Carer’s Allowance, at full or half-rate If you are aged under 70, your income is assessed by the HSE to see whether you qualify for a GP visit card. See below for information about the HSE basic rates of income.
results.question: Who can get a GP visit card?
results.answer: To qualify for a GP visit card, individuals must meet certain criteria, which includes being ordinarily resident in Ireland and meeting income eligibility requirements. Specifically, those aged under 70 must either qualify through means-tested benefits like Carer’s Allowance or Carer’s Benefit, or fall into other non-means-tested categories such as receiving a medical card. Additionally, children under the age of 8 may be eligible for a GP visit card if they meet the aforementioned conditions. For those aged 70 and older, the eligibility process involves assessing their income against the HSE's weekly basic rate of income, with additional allowances for children. Document 0 provides further details on how to apply and the income limits involved. In summary, anyone meeting these criteria can obtain a GP visit card, making it accessible to various segments of the population based on personal and financial status.

results.ground_truth: Online applications are completed in approximately 20 working days for first-time applicants. If you are applying by post, you should allow at least 8 weeks for your application to be processed (not including postage times). This period may be extended at certain times of the year due to increased application numbers. First-time postal applications from the UK take at least 8 weeks. You can check the Passport Service website for current processing times.
results.question: How long will my passport application take?
results.answer:
- For applications made online through Passport Online, the latest turnaround times are available on the Passport Service's website.
- If you choose to apply by post, the processing time starts when the Passport Office receives the documents you send.
- Applying online is generally quicker because it allows faster processing.
- However, it's important to keep in mind that there might be delays due to factors like holiday periods, peak demand times, or administrative tasks.
- In general, you can expect to receive your passport within about 8 weeks for online applications, although exact timelines can vary depending on the specific circumstances.
- Remember to allow extra time if you're planning to use the passport immediately upon its issuance.
- Don't forget to consider the additional steps needed if you're living abroad and need to notify authorities beforehand.
- Always monitor your account regularly and respond promptly to any requests for further documentation or updates.

results.ground_truth: A Police Certificate is an official statement about you issued by An Garda Síochána. It is used by people who have lived in Ireland and want to work or study abroad. It is required by some foreign authorities. A Police Certificate states your: Name Address Date of birth Criminal record in Ireland (this does not include adult cautions) A Police Certificate is normally valid for 1 year. You should also note that the Irish spent convictions legislation cannot be used to prevent disclosure when you are required to disclose information about your criminal convictions to another state.
results.question: What is a Police Certificate?
results.answer:
A Police Certificate is necessary when hunting deer in Ireland. To get one, you must first obtain a Deer Hunting Licence. Additionally, you'll need to prove your identity through various forms of identification such as a passport or driving license. For detailed steps on obtaining a Police Certificate, refer to the document titled 'Applying directly to the court'. In summary, having a Police Certificate allows individuals to legally engage in activities like deer hunting, ensuring compliance with laws and regulations related to firearms usage. Document 3:::
Garda Síochána's responsibilities
The Garda Síochána is responsible for enforcing the law and maintaining public safety across Ireland. Their main functions include dealing with crime, investigating suspicious incidents, providing security during major events, conducting traffic enforcement, managing emergency situations, and supporting other government agencies. They work closely with other law enforcement bodies and provide support to communities in times of crisis.

results.ground_truth: Each local authority maintains the Register of Electors for its area. To be included in the Register of Electors, you must: Be at least 18 years old Be ordinarily resident at an address in Ireland If you are homeless or have no address, you can still register to vote by stating that you have ‘no fixed address.’ Read more about being homeless and registering to vote. If you have more than one address, you should give the address where you want to be registered. You can only be registered at one address. You can register to vote: Online at checktheregister.ie By filling in an application form If you do not give a PPS number, you must get your form and ID witnessed at a local Garda station or your local authority.
results.question: How to register to vote?
results.answer:
To register to vote in Ireland, you can either:
- Online at checktheregister.ie
- Fill in a paper application form (ERF 2)
- Contact your local authority directly 
- Use the free An Post Address Point service
- Get your paper application form (ERF 2) and identity witnessed at a local Garda station  
- Provide your PPS number and address or Eircode
- State 'no fixed address' when registering online in Dublin
- Bring your ID when voting even if you have a polling card  
- Apply for anonymity as an elector through form PV7
- Update your details online at checktheregister.ie or by filling in a paper application form (ERF 2).  
- Your PPS number and date of birth will not be published on the electoral register.  
- Contact your local authority for assistance if needed.

results.ground_truth: The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant provides funding so you can refurbish vacant and derelict homes. It can also be used to renovate vacant and derelict properties that have not been used as residential properties before. However, this only applies if the non-residential properties were used for commercial or public use before and now have the correct planning permission. You can get the grant if you are refurbishing the vacant property so you can live there, or so you can rent the property out. You can get a grant of up to €50,000 to renovate a vacant property and up to €70,000, if the property is derelict. You can get more if you are living on an off-shore island. And, there is an additional grant for expert conservation advice if you are refurbishing a vacant traditional farmhouse. The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant is funded by the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage through the Croí Cónaithe (Towns) Fund and you apply to your local authority. If you have questions about the grant or want to know if your property qualifies, you can: Read the FAQs about the grant Contact the Vacant Homes Officer in your local authority Contact the Housing Agency's Vacancy Helpline on vacancycampaign@housingagency.ie You can also find information on how to re-use old and vacant buildings in the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage’s Bringing Back Homes (pdf) manual.
results.question: What is the Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant?
results.answer: The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant is a government program that provides funding for the renovation of vacant properties. Under this program, owners of vacant properties can receive up to €50,000 for renovations, while those who wish to convert them into dwellings can receive up to €70,000. The grant is inclusive of VAT costs associated with the works carried out. Additionally, it's worth noting that there are specific guidelines regarding the types of work that can be funded, as well as the eligibility criteria for different types of properties. For instance, the grant covers demolition work and site clearance, as well as superstructure works like wall repairs, chimney replacements, and structural timber reinforcement. It also includes external completions such as door installation, window replacements, and skirting installations. On the other hand, internal completions like door frames, architraves, and ironmongery are within the scope of the grant too.

results.ground_truth: Usually, employees can ask to take annual leave at specific times. Your employer can accept your request, or refuse your request. Your employer decides when annual leave may be taken, but this is subject to a number of conditions. Your employer must: Take into account your family responsibilities, as well as the available opportunities for rest and recreation. Discuss your annual leave with you (or your union) at least one month before you are to take the leave.
results.question: Can my employer force me to take annual leave?
results.answer: Yes, usually, employees can ask to take annual leave at specific times. However, depending on the situation, your employer may refuse your request. Your employer decides when annual leave may be taken, but they must consider factors such as your family responsibilities and the availability of rest and recreation. If you disagree with your employer's decision, you can appeal the decision through internal processes or seek external help from human resources or legal advice. Additionally, there are provisions allowing employees to negotiate flexible working arrangements to accommodate personal needs while maintaining productivity.

results.ground_truth: If you are sick while you are on annual leave, you should get a medical certificate from your GP (doctor) as soon as possible to cover the days you were sick. Give the medical certificate to your employer as soon as you return to work. This way, the sick days will not count as annual leave, and you can take your annual leave at a later date. Your employer cannot make you to take annual leave for time you were on certified sick leave.
results.question: What if I get sick while on annual leave?
results.answer: Starting from 1 January 2024, you have a right to 5 days’ sick pay a year. This is called statutory sick pay. Since 1 January 2024, you have a right to 5 days’ sick pay a year. Starting from 1 January 2024, you have a right to 5 days’ sick pay a year.

results.ground_truth: Generally, your landlord can only end a tenancy after the first 6 months if: You do not comply with the obligations of the tenancy, for example, by not paying your rent on time The property is no longer suited to your needs, for example, if it is too small The landlord intends to sell the property within 9 months. However, this may not apply if the landlord plans to sell 10 or more dwellings in a development within a 6-month period – see ‘Restriction on terminating when selling multiple properties’ below The landlord needs the property for their own use or for an immediate family member (this only applies to private landlords) The landlord plans to change the use of the property (for example, convert it from residential use to office use) The landlord intends to refurbish the property substantially
results.question: What is a valid reason for ending a tenancy after the first 6 months?
results.answer:
After the first 6 months, a valid reason for ending a tenancy includes specific circumstances such as damage to the property, non-payment of rent, or failure to comply with the terms of the lease. However, the key point is that the landlord must provide a valid notice of termination that specifies the reason for termination. Document 2:::
The legal framework governing tenancies in student-specific accommodation includes the Residential Tenancies (Amendment) Act 2024 and the Residential Tenancies (No. 2) Act 2021. These acts aim to ensure tenants' rights and protect landlords' interests while maintaining stability in the rental market. For instance, the 41-week limit ensures that students are not overburdened with commitments outside their academic schedules. Additionally, the act emphasizes the importance of communication and documentation in tenancy agreements, ensuring transparency and minimizing disputes.

results.ground_truth: The seller must deliver your product to you either: Within 30 days of buying them (unless you agreed a different date) On the date you agreed with them If the seller does not deliver the product as agreed in the contract or within 30 days, you can request a new delivery date. You can insist that all items you bought in the one transaction are delivered at once. The seller cannot make you accept deliveries in instalments. You can end the contract if: The seller cannot or refuses to deliver within the new time frame you request A new delivery date is no longer suitable for you, for example, you needed the product for a specific date or event You must tell the business you are using your right to end your contract for non-delivery. The business must give you a refund within 14 days. The European Consumer Centre (ECC) Ireland has a letter template which may be helpful.
results.question: What are your rights when an order is delayed or not delivered?
results.answer:
If your delayed or non-delivery, you have the following rights:

- Within 30 days of buying the item, you must get the item within this time frame (unless you agreed to a different delivery time)
- You must provide proof that the seller gave you all necessary information
- If you received faulty items, you can request a replacement or repair
- If you paid through a bank transfer, the seller must refund the money within 14 days of receiving the goods back
- If the delay caused loss or damage, you have the right to claim compensation
- In some situations, you may be able to choose a different delivery option without paying extra charges

results.ground_truth: To adopt a child, you must be at least 21 years of age and resident in Ireland. If you are adopting the child as a couple, and one of you is the child’s mother or father or relative, only one of you must be at least 21. There is no upper age limit for adoptive parents. You can adopt if you are: A married couple living together A couple living together in a civil partnership A couple cohabiting together (living together and in a committed relationship) for at least 3 years The mother, father or relative of the child (relative meaning a grandparent, brother, sister, uncle or aunt of the child, and/or the spouse of any such person; the relationship to the child being traced through the mother or the father) If you are a sole applicant (applying for adoption on your own), and you do not fall into any of the categories listed above, you may only adopt if the Adoption Authority of Ireland is satisfied with the particular circumstances of the case.
results.question: Who can adopt a child in Ireland?
results.answer: In Ireland, individuals over the age of 21 years old are eligible to adopt. However, there is no specific upper age limit set by Irish law. To qualify as a suitable candidate, applicants must demonstrate good health, stability, maturity, and the ability to provide a nurturing environment for the child. Additionally, both biological parents must consent to the adoption, except in cases where one parent is deceased, incapacitated, or unable to consent due to incapacity. The adoption process involves various assessments, including a declaration of eligibility and suitability, to ensure that all parties involved meet certain criteria for suitability. Document 2 provides further guidance on obtaining necessary documentation and completing the adoption process.

results.ground_truth: Penalty points are recorded on your driving licence when: You are convicted in court of a driving offence that attracts penalty points or You pay a fixed charge notice that was issued to you for an offence that also carries penalty points If you get 12 penalty points in any 3 year period, you are automatically disqualified from driving for 6 months. Learner permit drivers are disqualified if they have 7 penalty points. This lower threshold also applies for the first 2 years of a driver’s first full driving licence. Penalty points are not added to your licence immediately. Fixed charge and penalty offences Fixed notice penalties are issued for driving offences that attract penalty points and/or just a fine. If you receive a fixed notice penalty, you will be issued a notice by the Department of Transport. If you pay the fixed charge fine within 56 days, you will get a further notice from the Department of Transport confirming that the penalty points will be added to your driving licence. The penalty points will be added to your licence 28 days after that. If you do not pay the fixed charge fine within 56 days, you will get a summons to appear in the District Court. If you are convicted of a driving offence in court, the court will notify the Department of Transport of the number of penalty points attached to that conviction. The Department of Transport will then issue a notification that these penalty points will be added to your driving licence 28 days after the notification date. You can get information on fixed charge notices and fines in our document on driving offences.
results.question: How do penalty points work?
results.answer:
Penalty points are recorded on your driving licence when:
- You are convicted in court of a driving offence that attracts penalty points
- You pay a fixed charge notice that was issued to you for an offence that also carries penalty points

For example, if you speed and are fined €160, you'll receive 3 penalty points. If you're convicted in court, you might receive 5 penalty points and a fine of up to €5,000.

When you reach 12 penalty points, you automatically lose your license for 6 months.

These points are not visible on the physical licence; they are stored in a record that insurers can access.

Points are added over time through convictions and fixed charges. They last for 3 years before being removed, unless additional points were accrued while suspended.

To avoid accumulating too many points, it's important to pay all fines promptly, even those that weren't initially required.

results.ground_truth: To be eligible for a statutory redundancy payment, you must: Be over 16 Be in employment that is fully insurable under the Social Welfare Acts Have at least 2 years’ continuous employment (104 weeks) with the same employer over the age of 16 Have been made redundant (dismissed from your job). You must have been dismissed from your job To show you were dismissed, your employment must have been terminated (with or without notice). There will also be a dismissal if you have ended your contract of employment because you were forced to leave your job because of your employer’s conduct. This is known as constructive dismissal.
results.question: Do I have a right to redundancy pay?
results.answer:
Yes, you have a right to redundancy pay if you lose your job. According to the relevant legislation, you are entitled to statutory redundancy pay upon meeting specific criteria such as having worked for a minimum period (2 years or 104 weeks). Additionally, you have the right to receive statutory redundancy pay whether you choose to accept it or not. Document 3:::
English | Gaeilge

You are here: Home > Employment > Unemployment and redundancy > Redundancy > What happens next? >

What happens next?

If you are made redundant, your employer must inform you in writing that they intend to terminate your employment and provide details of the reason why. This written notification is called a termination letter.

In some cases, your employer may offer you alternative employment or transfer you to another position within your current organization. In other situations, your employer may decide to let you go immediately without offering alternatives.

results.ground_truth: You must complete the application form and provide supporting documents. You can apply for most payments online. You can also get an application form from your local Intreo Centre or Social Welfare Branch Office or your local Citizens Information Centre. You can also get an application form on gov.ie. Your Intreo Centre, Social Welfare Branch Office or your local Citizens Information Centre can help you fill in your application form. Birth certs for social welfare You are no longer required to provide copies of birth certificates for social welfare purposes if you were born in Ireland and your birth is in the Register of Births. The Department of Social Protection can access this information directly. You can get more information about getting a Birth, Marriage or Death certificate.
results.question: How to apply for social welfare?
results.answer:
To apply for social welfare, you must complete the application form and provide supporting documents. You can apply for most payments online. You can also get an application form from your local Intreo Centre or Social Welfare Branch Office or your local Citizens Information Centre. You can also get an application form on gov.ie. Your Intreo Centre, Social Welfare Branch Office or your local Citizens Information Centre can help you fill in your application form. Additionally, there are specific requirements that you might be asked to meet during the application process, such as providing information about yourself, your family members, your employment status, and financial details. Once all necessary documentation is submitted, it typically takes several weeks for the application to be processed and reviewed by the Department of Social Protection. Document 3:::
Social welfare payments and benefits eligibility criteria
Social welfare payments and benefits eligibility criteria

Social welfare payments and benefits are designed to support individuals who meet certain criteria.

results.ground_truth: You must make comments about planning applications in writing to the local authority where the application was made. You may be able to do this on your local authority's website. If possible, you should quote the planning application's reference number. You must also give your: Name Address Phone number Email address (if you have one)
results.question: How can I comment on a planning application?
results.answer:
- To comment on a planning application, you must make comments about planning applications in writing to the local authority where the application was made.
- You may be able to do this on your local authority's website.
- You must also give your Name, Address, Phone number, Email address (if you have one).  
- Your submission or observation must be acknowledged by the local authority.  
- The local authority cannot make a decision on an application until they have had it for 5 weeks.  
- When the local authority decides on the planning application, you must be informed of their decision within 3 days of them making it.  
- If your submission is received after the deadline, it will be returned to you along with your fee.  
- You will also be contacted by your local authority to tell you that your submission can’t be considered.  
- The deadline for commenting on a planning application is 5 weeks from when the local authority received the planning application.

results.ground_truth: Citizens Information Services (CISs) provide face-to-face services to the public. Through trained staff and volunteers, CISs provide free, impartial and confidential information, advice and advocacy services to the public. Each Citizens Information Service covers a geographical area and delivers the service through a network of Citizen Information Centres (CICs). There are eight individual regional Citizens Information Services which are companies limited by guarantee and are registered charities. They cover the following areas: North Dublin, Dublin South, North Connacht and Ulster, North Leinster, North Munster, South Connacht, South Leinster and South Munster facilitating both rural and urban areas. CISs provide information on various topics, including; Employment rights Income support Social welfare Family matters Health services Housing Education Immigration
results.question: What is the Citizens Information Service?
results.answer: The Citizens Information Service is supported by the Citizens Information Board, which is responsible for providing information, advice, and advocacy on public and social services. The service aims to ensure that citizens receive accurate, easily understandable information regarding their rights and entitlements, as well as assistance in applying for State services in Ireland. The board produces several publications related to rights and entitlements and funds other services such as the Money Advice and Budgeting Service and the National Advocacy Service for People with Disabilities. Additionally, the Citizens Information Board maintains the website citizensinformation.ie, which offers comprehensive information on public services and entitlements in Ireland. Document 1 mentions that one can reach the Citizens Information Service via the Citizens Information Phone Service at 0818 07 4000, while Document 2 suggests contacting the Citizens Information Centre nearest to them. Furthermore, both documents indicate that individuals can send feedback to the Citizens Information Board by email.

results.ground_truth: People aged between 18 and 24 and: Had been out of work and getting a qualifying payment (see below) for at least 12 months or Faced a significant barrier to work (if unemployed for less than 12 months) What were the qualifying payments? You must have been getting one of the following payments for at least 12 months: Jobseeker's Benefit, Jobseeker's Allowance, Jobseeker's Transitional payment, One-Parent Family Payment, Disability Allowance, Blind Person’s Pension, or Supplementary Welfare Allowance. Other schemes that counted towards the qualifying period The 12-month qualifying period could also have included time spent on schemes such as: SOLAS training apprenticeships, Youthreach, Back to Education Allowance, Fastrack to Information Technology and Tús.
results.question: Who was eligible for YESS (Youth Employment Support Scheme)?
results.answer:
Based on the given information, the eligibility criteria for the Youth Employment Support Scheme (YESS) were as follows:

- **Age**: Eligible participants were aged between 18 and 24 years old.

- **Unemployment Status**:
   - Participants had to be unemployed for at least 12 consecutive months.
   - For those unemployed for less than 12 months, there was a requirement to demonstrate a significant barrier to employment.

- **Social Welfare Payment**: They needed to be receiving a qualifying social welfare payment during the 12-month period.

- **Host Organisation Participation**: 
   - Host organizations could be in the private sector, community sector, or voluntary sector.
   - Public service bodies like schools and colleges were excluded from hosting placements.

- **Voluntary Nature**: Participation was entirely voluntary, with no financial penalties for non-participation or dropping out of the program.

results.ground_truth: If you are a carer you may need to take breaks. Respite care is when you can take a break from caring, and the person you care for is looked after by someone else. It can be covered by family members or an organisation so you can take a short break, a holiday or a rest. Respite care can be for carers of older people or people with different disabilities. Respite care can cover different lengths of time such as: A very short time, for example for an evening Or a much longer arrangement, for example for a holiday Respite care schemes are sometimes called 'Breakaway' or 'Friendship' schemes.
results.question: What is respite care?
results.answer:
Respite care is when a caregiver takes a break from caregiving responsibilities and has another individual take care of the person they are caring for. It can involve shorter periods like an evening or longer arrangements such as holidays. Respite care can be organized either within families or through organizations, depending on location. It helps caregivers relax or take a vacation while ensuring the person being cared for receives proper attention. 

Respite care for children with disabilities includes various methods of care, such as one-on-one care with a caregiver, overnight stays at residential facilities, and even overnights at summer camps funded by the HSE. For older adults, it might occur in nursing homes or other institutional settings. Document 2 explains how respite care works and mentions that respite care grants are available for carers under certain conditions. Additionally, the document indicates that carers can apply for carer's support grants which can help them manage the financial aspects of taking respite care.

results.ground_truth: If you have a medical card, you can get certain health services free of charge. Usually, your dependent spouse or partner and your children can also get the same range of health services for free. Your medical card is issued by the Health Service Executive (HSE).
results.question: What is a medical card?
results.answer: A medical card is a document issued by the Health Service Executive (HSE) that allows individuals to access healthcare services through a designated doctor or hospital. This card enables recipients to receive free or reduced-cost treatment for various ailments and conditions. Individuals can apply for a medical card either online or by visiting a local health center or office. Once approved, the card entitles its holder to specific benefits and services related to their health needs. Document 2 provides further details on how medical cards work, including eligibility criteria and renewal procedures. However, it's important to note that the process described here might differ slightly depending on individual circumstances and local policies. Document 0 mentions that medical cards serve as a legal document authorizing individuals to utilize healthcare resources. They are designed to facilitate easier access to essential medical care for those who meet certain qualifications, such as having a chronic illness, being elderly, or needing frequent medical attention.

results.ground_truth: Pre-nuptial agreements have no basis in law in Ireland. As a result, they are not strictly binding. This means that if you have a pre-nuptial agreement in place and you end up in court following the breakdown of your marriage, the judge is not bound by the terms of the pre-nuptial agreement. The only provision in Irish law is under sections 113 and 113A of the Succession Act 1965 (as amended) where a spouse or a civil partner can renounce his/her legal right share in a pre-nuptial agreement. Although they are not legally binding, there is nothing in Irish law which stops a couple planning to marry from having and signing a pre-nuptial agreement. Importantly, such agreements can serve as guides for the courts in judicial separation and divorce cases. If a pre-nuptial agreement makes ‘proper provision’ for each person it is more likely to be persuasive on the judge. Therefore, in situations where one party is likely to inherit a significant family farm or business, it will guide the judge in the divorce or judicial separation on what the parties’ intentions were at the outset.

results.ground_truth: The Department of Transport regulates air transport. This includes commercial and private services. EU airlines can fly freely within the EU/European Economic Area (EEA). They can do this without any restrictions on flight frequency or routes. Airlines from countries outside of the EU/EEA must request permission. They must do this each time they want to fly to, from, or over Ireland. The Department of Defence regulates military air transport in Ireland.
results.question: Who regulates aviation in Ireland?
results.answer: The Department of Transport regulates air transport in Ireland. This includes commercial and private services. Additionally, there are agencies like the Irish Aviation Authority (IAA) which handles safety, security, and consumer protection functions. Furthermore, the Department of Defence regulates military air transport in Ireland. Document 1 mentions that the Financial Services and Pensions Ombudsman (FSPO) oversees elections and refers to legislation such as the Air Navigation and Transport Act 2022, which set up AirNav Ireland and made the IAA the single aviation regulator for Ireland. Finally, Document 2 notes that the Irish Aviation Authority (IAA) is a commercial semi-state agency responsible for safety, security, and consumer protection functions.

results.ground_truth: Under the Cycle to Work Scheme (also known as the Bike to Work Scheme), you can get a new bike tax free through your work. Your employer pays for a new bike and then you repay the cost of regular instalments from your gross (overall) salary. You do not have to pay tax, PRSI or the Universal Social Charge on your repayments. Not every employer takes part in the scheme. However, if they do, they must offer it to all their employees. If you are self-employed, you cannot take part in the Cycle to Work Scheme unless you pay PRSI as an employee in addition to your self-employed work.
results.question: What is the Cycle to Work Scheme?
results.answer: Bike types covered under the Cycle to Work Scheme include cargo

results.ground_truth: Operating hours vary by stop and direction of service. You can view Luas operating hours and Luas frequency on luas.ie. There are electronic displays telling you the time of the next tram at every Luas stop. In addition, there are electronic displays and announcements informing passengers of the next stop on board every tram. Special services operate during Christmas, New Year and on other occasions.
results.question: What are the operating hours and frequency of the Luas?
results.answer:
The Luas operates with varying operating hours depending on the specific route. For example, the Green Line runs from Bride's Glen to Broombridge, while the Red Line goes from Saggart to The Point in Dublin Docklands. On average, the Luas operates approximately every 8 minutes during peak hours and every 12-15 minutes during off-peak times. To find out the exact schedule for a particular route, one can visit the Luas website (<https://www.luas.ie>). Additionally, electronic displays located at each Luas stop show the current time and the expected arrival of the next tram. Furthermore, announcements are made throughout each tram to inform passengers of their upcoming stops. Document 0:::
Luas is a public transport tram system that operates in Dublin, Ireland. The name Luas is the Irish word for speed. This tram system connects suburban parts of Dublin on 2 tramlines running through the city centre.
